question.message: Browse the globe to find new and amazing solutions, or click the button below for more guidance.

options.option: Ok, let's find way to harness technology.

question.message: Are you sure?
Technology can provide solutions to so many of societies defects.

options.option: You're right, let's find a solution!

question.message: With technology, you can accelerate your response to the virus.
Do you want to take action to prevent contagion?

options.option: Ok, let's get society up and running again
Let the virus run its course.

question.message: But social distancing is slowing down the economy!
A technological solution will help get things back to normal in no time :)

node.name: BT - ANON - LOC - HARD - APP or NA

question.message: Let's get connected!
When access to data is limited, the tech industry has clever ways to find more.
And with the pandemic, they are proving to be especially helpful by using different forms of hardware to map the location of users anonymously.
With generosity, they are informing governments how the virus might be spreading throughout a society.
Do you want to find a solution that builds physical infrastructure to connect untapped users to this viral map?
Or one that uses an app to pinpoint user locations through their engagement with technological infrastructure around them?

node.name: BT - ANON - LOC - SOFT - APP or NA

question.message: Let's crunch some location data!
The amount of information that private tech companies can collect and process far exceeds the capabilities of any one nation.
Globalization drives innovation once again!
Many existing apps are already capable of using their infrastructure to provide a solution for managing virus hotspots, and can be deployed at scale right away.
But the tech industry is always willing to build better ways to cross-reference location data, making predictive models more accurate.
Do you want to find a fast, scalable solution to locate viral hotspots?
Or invest in a new, precise solution to predict future hotspots?

node.name: BT - ANON - LOC - SOFT or HARD

question.message: Good thinking. Users are familiar with tech companies knowing their location, so there should be less resistance to this solutions.
Plus they already have the tools to do this.
Do you want to harness their sophisticated software to provide insights into how user location impacts viral transmission?
Or find an infrastructural solution that connects users to these companies, allowing them to locate users better?

node.name: BT - ANON - ACT - HARD - APP or NA

question.message: Let's find a new digital perspective on the virus.
Through adapting the sensing capabilities of user's personal devices, hardware can become a proxy for the virus itself. Now that's clever!
Do you want to find a solution that adapts an existing app to make use of this sensor, making participation more engaging?
Or find a way to transform the personal device into a viral sensor for a more streamlined solution?

node.name: BT - ANON - ACT - SOFT - APP or NA

question.message: Let's find a way to encrypt bodily interactions!
Understanding how the virus is transmitted is just as important as finding treatment.
So a great solution would allow for the cross-referencing of bodily information in a private, yet accessible way.
Do you want to find a solution that encrypts this information locally within an app to encourage adoption?
Or find a way to encrypt within a centralised but accessible system?

node.name: BT - ANON - ACT - SOFT or HARD

question.message: Smart choice, the bodily behaviour of users is a great way of predicting how the virus is behaving too.
But as this information becomes more detailed, it's a good strategy to make it anonymous so users will be more willing to share it, great thinking to combine the two!
And the tech industry has so many innovative techniques for linking together bits of information about our activities.
Do you want me to find a solution that uses software to do this?
Or a solution that uses sensors to gather more information?
Nice thinking!
Anonymity from government snooping has recently been seen as a big asset that the tech giants can provide users, much to the FBI's dismay.
So trusting them with data might feel easier for users, creating the mass adoption needed to make an effective solution.
A tech-led anti-virus solution would also make their intimate knowledge of our lives feel more natural, and boost their reputation - some extra motivation to help!
It's a win - win!
Should the solution use their expertise to either monitor the spread of the virus through user behaviour, or monitor through user location?

content.title: Data breach immunisation

bubbles.message: Let's look for a local solution!

Apps are meant to be easy for users to use, but to encourage the level of herd-installation needed to monitor activities effectively, privacy is a prerequisite. Encryption software embedded within the phone itself can help with this.

content.content:
**Data breach immunisation**


If agreement can be reached between the competing makers of these operating system, fundamental alterations can be made within the programming of smartphone devices to allow them to communicate 'cross-platform'. By keeping it local, this solution will also assure users that their activity data is off limits to governments!

content.title: Encrypted cloud diagnosis

bubbles.message: Knowing the medical condition of users is more useful when it can be cross referenced with the population; establishing trends in infection and recovery.

And with a commercial solution, this cross-referencing can be international; streamed around the world! This is difficult within the insular structures of national medical institutes. Too slow for such a speedy virus!

content.content:
**Encrypted cloud diagnosis**


With the support of cloud computing companies, and the sophisticated algorithms they use to analyse data, this solution can streamline medical diagnosis of the virus. It can also protect user privacy through their world-leading encryption services.

node.name: BT - ID - LOC - HARD - APP or NA

question.message: Communication infrastructure is needed to handle any type of data about our activities.
The physical location of this hardware can change how effective this solution can be.
Do you want me to look into a sovereign hardware solution?
Or hardware that can centralises and process information from anywhere around the world, taking advantage of the best available service?

content.title: Centralised warning system for contagion zone breach

bubbles.message: With the government in charge of developing the app solution, you can build in privacy measures that match their stance on data protection.

content.content:
**Centralised warning system for contagion zone breach**


This system runs via apps, utilising the ubiquity or personal bluetooth transmitters within citizen's smartphone devices. The intersection of bluetooth signals between two citizens triggers the exchange of anonymous IDs that are stored centrally, so warning information can be sent from this central location to those who have had dangerously close contact.

node.name: BT - ID - LOC - SOFT - APP or NA

question.message: Let's get c0ding.
Software can cross-reference and centralise geolocation information of different users to create a more accurate picture of who is close to who.
(and why)
Do you want to find an app solution that lets users feel part of the tracking process?
Or find a solution that operates behind the scenes? - out of sight, out of mind?

content.title: Debit distancing

bubbles.message: Changes made to information processing technologies can have wide-sweeping impact on behaviour, especially in a commercial context.

content.content:
**Debit distancing**


Through removing the hygiene risks associated with physical currency and proximity of exchange, facilitating the use of digital money can reduce the transmission of the virus while accelerating a transition to the digitisation of public institutes. Let's streamline economic activity!

node.name: BT - ID - LOC - SOFT or HARD

question.message: Bold choice - I like it!
During times of crisis, users may be more open to using the identification and geolocating techniques developed by the tech industry.
Even if it's slightly invasive, they'll thank you later when you've come out on top!
Do you want look for a software solution that improves the way users are traced (with or without the virus)?
Or re-purpose existing infrastructure to reveal new insights into their movements?

content.title: Unhealthy Machine learning

bubbles.message: Straight to the data. Nice work.
Let's find a resourceful solution that can extrapolate known information about different types of activity relevant to the virus to help anticipate potential infection zones.

content.content:
**Unhealthy Machine learning**


This solution uses a machine learning algorithm to process information about unhealthy living conditions that damage lung tissue. While projecting risk zones of highly infectable citizens geographically, this solution simultaneously maps poverty within a territory.

node.name: BT - ID - ACT - SOFT - APP or NA

question.message: Users have (1) new update!
Software can be used to change how, and what information is transmitted; leading to potential changes in user behaviour.
Should I look for a solution that changes the way information about the virus transmits within apps?
Or look for a software upgrade that lowers the risk of viral transmission by facilitating non-contact behaviour?

content.title: Personal contagion zone virtualisation unit

bubbles.message: I like where your head's at.
This means that even those citizens without smartphones can be included within the solution.
Determining the location of users with GPS is often inaccurate, and doesn't give a clear picture of how close individuals are, or how long they have been together.

content.content:
**Personal contagion zone virtualisation unit**


This solution can help solve problems presented by GPS tracking by instead measuring the distance between citizens, and how long they have been in close contact, while also exchanging anonymous identification keys. If one user in this exchange becomes infected, a warning message can be shared with every other user that has been in a dangerous proximity with them.

node.name: BT - ID - ACT - HARD - APP or NA

question.message: Let's get building!
New infrastructure is a great way to enable users and authorities to connect; encouraging anti-viral behaviour.
And big-tech LOVES to connect people.
This solution could also have long term benefits if it prompts users to become more open to new ways to organise society.
Should I find a solution that incorporates apps to do this in a more user-centric way?
Or find a more top-down approach?

content.title: Contagion of things

bubbles.message: Unlike cellular and wifi hardware, bluetooth chips are designed to form local networks, called piconets. Cute right? As a piconet only connects to nearby devices, a user's information doesn't need to be centralised, allowing for more anonymity.

content.content:
**Contagion of things**


This solution uses the strength of bluetooth signals from smartphone devices to measure the distance between users, as well as the duration of close proximity, to quantify a risk of contagion. As Bluetooth chips are an internationally recognised radio-transmission technology, the application of such a solution is also potentially universal!

node.name: BT - ID - ACT - SOFT or HARD

question.message: Preventive intervention - nice direction.
With so much of daily life becoming digitised, it's a great idea to see how digitisation can help 'nudge' users away from behaviour that could spread the virus.
Especially if a behaviour change is what's needed to deal with the longevity of the pandemic.
As a bonus, a solution can push through digitisation measures that had some friction pre-pandemic!
Do you want to find a quick solution, where tech companies create behaviour-change through software-change?
Or one with a long-term vision, facilitating behaviour change by installing new infrastructure?

content.title: Anti-body-workout

bubbles.message: New forms of personal body sensors, such as 'fitness wearables', have become big-business for the tech industry over the past decade. They've also bred a new genre of fitness apps to datafy the body. Let's find one that can detect the virus!

content.content:
**Anti-body-workout**


An upgraded fitness app can anonymise and share user health data to establish medical trends that indicate susceptibility, or resistance to the virus.

question.message: Let's get to know the users.
This will make a solution more targeted. Which is just what big-tech has specialised in doing!
Users are already accustomed to sharing their identities with these companies, so a bit more data might go unnoticed.
When is comes to the pandemic, this information can help provide valuable insights into where and how the virus is spreading.
Do you want to find a solution that lowers the risk transmission by influencing user behaviour?
Or one that focuses on locating the virus through locating users?

content.title: Viral sonification analysis

bubbles.message: Before the virus is 'received', it needs to be 'transmitted'. If you can detect risk at the source of transmission, perhaps we can isolate users without intervention from central authorities.

content.content:
**Viral sonification analysis**


Through utilising the ubiquity of personal microphone transducers in smartphone devices, citizens can assess the risk-factor of transmission before the act occurs. By focusing solely on the vocal anomalies that indicate infection, the citizen's identity does not need to be known. Personal diagnosis - personal responsibility!

question.message: Smart thinking!
As they compete to make the best products and services, the giants of the tech industry lead the way on innovation; they even find solutions to problems we didn't know we had!
And as they form connections to just about everyone who uses digital communication technologies, these networks can serve as a proxy for possible viral transmission.
The tech giants are truly 'pan' (all) 'demic' (people) companies!
I can look for an anti-virus solution that gets intimate with a user's identities.
Or go wide - taking advantage of their massive datasets to reveal insightful trends that indicate the spread of virus, while hiding the identities of users within the collective.

content.title: Intra-national network transmission monitoring system

bubbles.message: Utilising public infrastructure can be a great way to get a snapshot of the entire territory. Especially if it's one that's used by so many of the population.

content.content:
**Intra-national network transmission monitoring system**


This network of transportation sensors can map changes in the location of citizens without identifying them individually. This minimally invasive solution can assure citizens that the government is monitoring the spread of the virus, without needing to engage through personal communication devices.

node.name: GOV - ANON - ACT  - HARD - APP or NA

question.message: A viral sixth sense!
Personal sensors can link citizens and the virus at a 1 to 1 scale.
A citizen's activities digitised and assessed without the need of centralised observation - that's a plus for citizens concerned about privacy!
Do you want a solution that uses an app to provide direct, and personalised analysis of this activity?
Or find a solution that has autonomy from smartphone ecosystems?

content.title: Aerial-antivirus-amplification

bubbles.message: The internet needs to be transmitted as far and wide as the virus itself in order for governments to keep up with the speed of the contagion. Vital information about the virus can also spread through this network, preparing remote users for the risks to come.
This means those out of reach in remote locations need to get 'on the grid'.

content.content:
**Aerial-antivirus-amplification**


If installing internet cables across vast, rugged terrain is difficult, look to the sky! An airborne internet solution can overcome such obstacles. With governments not able to commodify user data, it becomes difficult to justify such an expense. But if the tech industry can assist in reaching vulnerable users, while also creating additional data streams, it might be worth their while!

node.name: GOV - ANON - ACT  - SOFT - APP or NA

question.message: Let's find a way to look into citizen's anonymous data for a more nuanced analysis of their activities.
Without knowing anyone by name, anonymous activity data can provide an overview of communities while still preserving privacy.
Do you want a solution that gathers this information through an app that citizens install themselves?
Or act quicker by sourcing information from an existing database?

content.title: Charge displacement mapping

bubbles.message: As the virus impacts different regions at different times, a solution that can determine if a user is visiting or moving to a location can calibrate the antiviral response.

content.content:
**Charge displacement mapping**


Through analysing the battery charge of a user's device, this solution can determine the relationship this user has with a particular location. Is the virus on a vacation? Or moving to a new spot. Home is where you have a full battery!

node.name: GOV - ANON - ACT  - SOFT or HARD

question.message: Great, let's see if we can find a solution that can also restore normal activity; we don't want society to collapse!
Getting a sense of how citizens are behaving can provide a more accurate picture of how the virus is transmitted within a location.
Citizens will also have more trust in a system that does not know where they are at all times.
Do you want to find a solution that uses a sensors to gather this activity information?
Or one that dives into existing data?

content.title: Anti-contagion de-localisation device

bubbles.message: Removing unwanted citizens from public space is a way to generate physical anonymity, while also preventing the spread of the virus!

content.content:
**Anti-contagion de-localisation device**


This hardware solution prompts citizens to stay away from public utilities by supplying them with access to apps that replace the services that they normally obtain from centralised public points of possible contagion.

node.name: GOV - ANON -  LOC - SOFT - APP or NA

question.message: The right data can help scale a solution instantly!
This is crucial for a solution that locates citizens across an entire territory.
If you want to find a novel way to gather location data anonymously, a new app could help.
But if you use existing forms of governmental data, you can make participation mandatory.

content.title: Societal Messaging System (SMS)

bubbles.message: Quick thinking, let's find a quick response.
Without having to spend time developing an app (and convincing the public to download it) we can act with the speed necessary to stop the exponential spread of the virus!

content.content:
**Societal Messaging System (SMS)**


This solutions utilises the pan-demic communication medium that is SMS messaging to counter the highly-communicable and widespread nature of the virus. The government can DM anonymous information about possible contact with infected citizens.

node.name: GOV - ANON -  LOC - HARD - APP or NA

question.message: Good move!
Hardware can sense where the virus could be through locating or distancing citizens.
Should we look for an citizen-centric app solution that uses hardware to help increase the anonymity of citizens?
Or take the lead and find a solution that's embedded within public infrastructure?

content.title: Artificial Infection (AI) simulation

bubbles.message: When supercomputers aren't busy defeating the best human minds in games of chess and go, their attention is focused on solving some of the most complex mysteries of the universe; from understanding the intricacies of our DNA, to rewinding the creation of the universe.
Understanding the contagion of the virus shouldn't be too difficult!

content.content:
**Artificial Infection (AI) simulation**


AI analysis of user locations can be used to simulate different scenarios of contagion based on variables of mobility in a population.

node.name: GOV - ANON -  LOC - SOFT or HARD

question.message: Smart strategy.
If you know where citizens are, you know where the virus could be. And without revealing identity info, citizens will be more accepting of a solution that gathers information about their location.
Do you to find a solution that utilises physical infrastructure to do this? Or find a new way to process data?

content.title: Anti-viral detours

bubbles.message: Navigation apps already know how to use our location to offer the best routes (and the best ads), while also anonymously warning us about densely populated areas (traffic). This process could be adapted to offer virus protection as part of their business model. Now that's great service!

content.content:
**Anti-viral detours**


By combining information from the collective location of user's devices, together with publicly available transportation data, this solution shows users which nearby locations and transportation methods are a potential contagion hotspot.

question.message: Sounds wise to me!
A solution that keeps identities anonymous has a greater chance of gaining public support, which is a must if you are going to achieve the cohesive response needed for this solution to work.
Herd immunity? More like herd trust!
Do you want a solution that monitors the locations of anonymous citizens? Or would you prefer to focus on their activities?

content.title: Viral heat maps

bubbles.message: Locating citizens can feel overbearing, so by making an app voluntary, citizens can feel more in control of the solution. New ways to visualise the location of infected citizens anonymously can also help ease the anxieties of being victimised!

content.content:
**Viral heat maps**


By mapping the general area which an infected citizen has travelled in the previous day, this solution visualises the risk of possible contagion geographically. If the citizen hasn't been in the contagion zones, they can get back to business as usual!

node.name: GOV - ID - LOC - SOFT - APP or NA

question.message: Good choice!
A data oriented solution can help you connect different sources of information to locate citizens more precisely.
Do you want your solution to gather data through an app to track the virus on the go?
Or find a solution that coordinates information to monitor citizens in specific locations?

content.title: Viral selfie analysis

bubbles.message: Instead of using telecommunication data to guess how citizens are behaving, let's find an inventive solution to analyse a citizen's behaviour; spotting possible points of contagion that are not intelligible through location data alone.

content.content:
**Viral selfie analysis**


Apps can also communicate with the imagery stored within the photo libraries of a user's personal device. Users may be close, but were they wearing masks? Or kissing? Analysis of intimate visual information provides richer knowledge about the risks and precautions users are taking to prevent transmission of the virus.

node.name: GOV - ID - LOC - HARD - APP or NA

question.message: Good move!
Physical hardware can be used to connect the dots between the identity and location of citizens.
This approach could focus on each citizen separately, or be omnipresent.
Do you want to find a hardware solution that can combine with an app for more personalisation?
Or find an infrastructural solution that gathers more information about citizen's movements at the population scale?

content.title: Information quarantine measures

bubbles.message: Information about the virus can drastically alter the actions that users take when infected.

Communications apps have become a primary source of knowledge for users in developed countries, but as the tech industry makes it easier and easier to share (and gather) information, this can be either a helpful or harmful in fighting the virus.

content.content:
**Information quarantine measures**


Through manipulating the way information can be shared within dominant messaging ecosystems—while also identifying and blocking those that transmit false information—users can take more informed action to stop the spread of the virus, and seek treatment.

node.name: GOV - ID - LOC - SOFT or HARD

question.message: Smart strategy.
If you know where citizens are, you know where the virus could be.
If you also know WHO they are, you can also find out if they're somewhere they shouldn't be.
Do you want to find a solution that utilises physical sensors to do this? Or focus on processing data?

content.title: Non-contact contact keys

bubbles.message: The spread of the virus can be controlled by providing or denying access to different services and locations. Biometric information can automatically assess permissions without the need for physical documents.

content.content:
**Non-contact contact keys**


By converting unique visual information from a citizen's face into a unique key-code, a combination of cameras, software, and a centralised database of identity data can control the movement of citizens throughout a territory. This solution lowers the risk of viral transmission caused by contact with keys, keypads, and fingerprint scanners.

node.name: GOV - ID - ACT  - SOFT - APP or NA

question.message: Let's have a look...
Data analysis can create insights into past and future actions of the citizens too.
Do you want to find an app solution that gather personal info from a citizen's phone so you can reflect on past behaviour?
Or a solution that uses software to analyse information about a citizen directly?

content.title: Cloud control

bubbles.message: Apps can send data to a central location to make sense of; the relationship between the location of users; the spread of the virus; and other geographical data. It's like looking down on the society as a petri dish!

content.content:
**Cloud control**


The data collected about user-movements within a central 'cloud' server can be used to distribute warning messages to those at risk of infection. Big-tech are already professionals at centralising, processing, and distributing data; how else can the world binge-watch a complete season Stranger Things in one week!

node.name: GOV - ID - ACT - HARD - APP or NA

question.message: I SENSE you're on the right track!
Sensors can be used to detect activities that increase the risk of transmission.
Do you want this sensor to work with an app to detect more personal information about a citizen's activity?
Or make the sensor 'social', embedding it within infrastructure to pay attention to activity in public space?

content.title: Lens-code information interface

bubbles.message: So let’s think of a way we can use sensors to gather more information about a citizen’s activities at critical points of contagion. And if a safe distance can be maintained, it's a bonus!

content.content:
**Lens-code information interface**


By encoding identification information within a visual code, transmission of information can sent from an image on a citizen's smartphone screen to a camera. This lowers the risk of viral transmission through physical documents, while still allowing the user to retain information locally on a personal device.

content.title: High-speed anti-viral antenna

bubbles.message: Let's push users in a safe direction!

A solution that increases the use of communication apps will help lower the transmission risk of communicating in person, but more app use means more data! Better connectivity will make sure these communication apps appeal to users.

content.content:
**High-speed anti-viral antenna**

Installing infrastructure to boost the quality of digital communication apps—while also allowing more devices to be used simultaneously—can allow users to stay safe at home. Commercial activity can resume by turning more and more livingrooms into offices. No more need to check in and out of work!

node.name: GOV - ID - ACT  - SOFT or HARD

question.message: Actions speak louder than words!

Getting an idea of how citizens are behaving can give a more accurate picture of how the virus is spreading. And by combining this info with IDs, citizens might feel a little bit more responsible for their actions.
Do you want me to find a type of sensor to keep an eye on activity? Or find a way to do this through data?

content.title: Identification patrol units

bubbles.message: With government backing, we can also consider enlisting law enforcement apparatus to help stop the spread of the virus.

content.content:
**Identification patrol units**


This solution used automated, robotic sensors to navigate a territory, identifying citizens in order to regulate their actions in public space. Through a combination of cameras, speakers, and microphones, authorities can deter undesirable behaviour that is likely to increase the risk of viral transmission.

content.title: Emergency oversight apparatus

bubbles.message: Tracking and suppressing unauthorised protests or political decent is just one step away from controlling infected users and enforcing social distancing measures. So why not kill two birds with one stone?
Integrated tracking solutions have become the specialty of authoritarian regimes around the world.
But luckily, some are also commercialising and selling their systems to aid up-and coming dictatorships!

content.content:
**Emergency oversight apparatus**


This solution allows for the complete observation and management of users to track and control viral transmission. Through an all-seeing network of cameras, and sophisticated software for processing this visual information, dangerous behaviour can be deterred. What is deemed dangerous is up to you!

question.message: Let's get personal!
As the virus is jumping between families, friends, and colleagues, identity information can help reach the real-life social network of citizens.
Governments have citizen's ID info already, it should be put towards a good use!
Do you want to know citizen's location too? Or know more about what they're doing?

content.title: Contact elimination tracing

bubbles.message: Apps can give citizens a direct insight into the location of risky areas relative to their own position.  Roaming through a territory with their smartphone can be become a game of hide OR seek.

content.content:
**Contact elimination tracing**


This solution allows users to take an active role in monitoring risky encounters with users around them. With the location data of infected users being processed centrally by the government, and transmitted to all users who have been in the near vicinity, the process of circumventing risk zones can simultaneously uncover the exact locations of infected users.

content.title: App dispersal platform

bubbles.message: Great, let's reach out to users!
Apps provide direct access you useful information about individual users' location, but giving users access to these apps is equally important for maximum inclusion.

content.content:
**App dispersal platform**

Standardisation of apps can allow them be rolled out across large parts of the population. By adhering to the standards and regulations of multinational app distributors, you can allow anyone with a smartphone to download and participate in the viral tracking solution.

question.message: Good choice!
A government-led solution should make sure there’s no corporate agenda behind an anti-virus solution.
As a government has the identity information of the entire population, as well as control over hospitals and medical centers, they can also choose how to link infection info with citizens.
The question is; how much information do you gather and expose about citizens while creating an anti-virus solution?
I can find a solution that uses identity information to track infected citizens, or a solution that keeps their identities anonymous, encouraging them to participate.

content.title: Digital fence patrol system

bubbles.message: By focusing on software that bridges multiple sources of information, relying on a user to actively participate through an app becomes unnecessary.

content.content:
**Digital fence patrol system**

This solution draws a virtual containment parameter around the residence of a citizen by coordinating data from telecommunications companies, border customs, health agencies, and police; through one governmental software system. The two-week incubation period shapes the intensity of monitoring needed to create a quarantine enforcement solution for potentially infected, but definitely restless, citizens.

content.title: Infection infiltration system

bubbles.message: Many of the tracking techniques used by the tech industry are kept hidden from users, making their systems less frictional. As the virus spreads rapidly, it could be wise to avoid friction, and not wait for public consensus or approval of a suitable way to track users.

content.content:
**Infection infiltration system**

This system runs behind the scenes of the telecommunication infrastructure that connects personal devices to the network. Some telcos are not cooperative when it comes to handing over the identities of users unfortunately :( But by initiating this solution, identities can be pieced together from anonymous information in order to precisely monitor possible transmission between users.

options.option: Seek help from the tech industry.

question.message: Great decision, I'm happy to help!
If you’re a techno-solutionist like me, you know there’s no problem that technology can’t solve.
So with all the problems the coronavirus brings with it, developing new technologies—or repurposing old ones—is a great way to get things back to normal!
Based on the approach you’d like to take, I’ll propose a technological solution that matches your preferences, and show you how a different country has used it.
So let’s get started!
Taking action against this virus will take a group effort. So first you need to think about who should inspire this solidarity.
A government-led solution will have political power on its side. But the scale and speed of the tech industry could allow them to outpace the virus.
We can look for solutions that are led by governments; the citizen approach.
Or we can look for solutions that are led by the tech industry; the user approach.

content.title: Wearable warnings

bubbles.message: The personalisation of an app through a uniquely identifiable wearable can give a visual reminder to citizen's community of potential infection. Reprimands for breaking the rules associated with this hardware can then come from both the authorities, and the nervous citizens that spot rule-breaking.

content.content:
**Wearable warnings**


This solution makes precautionary quarantine orders digitized, and visualised. Identification information is transmitted by the app to alert authorities of a quarantine breach, while visual information transmitted by the sight of the wearable warns others of a social decency breach.

content.title: Reception prevention

bubbles.message: Location information is key to providing users with the best service, so the commercial sector has developed the best tools for the job. Making sure you know the location of the population would also be a great anti-coronavirus service!

content.content:
**Reception prevention**


The location of cellular devices are triangulated by telecommunication companies to determine which cell tower a user should be connected to. This solution takes advantage of this information to map how the virus moves with users across a territory.

content.view_deployment_button: View solution in use around the world

question.message: The coronavirus has circled the globe; finally finding its way to your secluded island nation.
Infections are on the rise, and as a representative of this nation, you’ve been tasked with finding an anti-virus solution to stem the uncontrollable spread of the virus.
But you’re in luck!
With so many examples of innovative anti-virus technologies being deployed around the world, there’s a solution out there to match any context.
Would you like me to help find the right match for you?

content.title: Global positioning solution (GPS)

bubbles.message: If a committed effort is made, physical Infrastructure can keep track of infected citizens nationwide at a granular level ... without having to rely on citizens to actively participate in the solution.
And under sovereign development, the maximum reach of this observation method is self-determined, allowing you to maximise the efficiency of such a solution.
But if you have a lot of ground to cover, we might need to aim high with our ambitions. Sky high...

content.content:
**Global positioning solution (GPS)**


This orbital infrastructure can coordinate with ground-based sensors to provide a holistic perspective of where citizens are; allowing for the containment or prediction of viral transmission throughout a territory.

message_bubbles.text: **Government institute:** Ministry of Social Development & Poverty Reduction, Government of British Columbia.
**Anonymisation method:** Citizens remain hidden from public.
**Location intervention:** Discouraging the visitation of public institutions.
**Hardware:** Android-based smartphones with internet connectivity.
**App use:** Common communication applications.

**Context:** Smartphones distributed to homeless citizens allow them to make contact with friends and relatives without relying on public institutions, such as libraries, for internet connectivity. As many of these spaces are unavailable due to social distancing, or have become hot zones for transmission, these devices—preloaded with $10 of data and the ability to connect to public wifi—are an anti-viral solution for the problems faced by a disconnected homeless community.
**Government institute:** Department for Transport.
**Anonymisation method:** Data aggregation.
**Location intervention:** Monitoring the redistribution of citizens across the territory.
**Hardware:** Various electronic sensors, including; 10,000 automatic traffic counters, public transport wireless ticketing systems, WiFi antennas, and electric vehicle charging stations.

**Context:** Traffic flow management has been converted into virus flow management, with these various sensors now determining if citizens are adhering to ‘stay at home’ orders. Based on what this infrastructure perceives, lock-down measures may be eased or strengthened in different parts of the territory.
**Government institute:** Ministry for Research, Innovation & Digital Policy.
**Anonymisation method:** Aggregation of data, stored on personal device and uploaded voluntarily.
**Location information:** Social heatmaps indicating general population density and movement.
**Software:** MIT 'safepaths' encryption and visualisation software.
**App:** CovTracer.

**Context:** Cyprus was one of the first countries in the world to deploy a contact tracing app, which locates citizens who may have come into contact with someone who has been diagnosed with Covid-19. The app allows citizens who have tested positive to the virus to share this information, and location history, with public health authorities, who can then visualise this information in maps showing generalised movements.
**Government institute:** The Ministry of Health and Welfare.
**Anonymisation method:** Infected citizen’s identities restricted to gender, age range, and assigned case number.
**Location information:** Infected citizens mapped geographically.

**Context:** By cross-referencing the location history of infected and non-infected citizens, SMS alerts are sent directly to those who have been at risk of infection. Additionally, the movements of infected citizens are publicly published online. Despite efforts to restrict the information revealed about the infected individuals, identification has still been possible by piecing together bits of the puzzle. This, together with the fatigue of receiving non-stop messages, has recently undermined South Korea’s successful solution for managing the outbreak.
**Government institute:** Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Lausanne (EPFL).
**Anonymisation method:** Anonymised and timestamped cough recordings, stored on private server.
**Activity information:** Cough analysis.
**Hardware use:** Microphone within user smartphone devices.
**App:** CoughVid.

**Context:** By processing audio signal through smartphone microphones, this solution then uses machine learning algorithms to automatically screens Covid-19 from the comfort of a citizen’s home. Such cough-sound analysis has already proven successful in diagnosing respiratory conditions like pertussis, asthma, and pneumonia. By uploading a cough anonymously to their servers, recognition of a covid-cough can be refined further, allowing healthcare workers and hospital facilities to share the burden of testing with citizens.
**Government institute:** Government Technology Agency (GovTech), together with Ministry of Health.
**Anonymisation method:** Citizen Bluetooth keychain exchange used instead of GPS coordinates. Data deleted after 25 days.
**Activity information:** Records of interactions between citizens logged.
**Hardware:** Bluetooth beacon - independent of smartphone.
**Platform:** Data processed internally by government through ‘TraceTogether’ system.

**Context:** After being one of first countries to initiate a smartphone-based Bluetooth contact tracing system, while also being celebrated for its attempt to integrate privacy measures, Singapore expanded its efforts by introducing Bluetooth tokens to include citizens without smartphones. Other countries had been interested in importing this Singapore's Bluetooth system, until a competing, seemingly more universal and privacy-preserving API was developed by Apple and Google.

content.title: France
content.status_comment: France’s coronavirus-tracing app failed to take off, with only 68 people using it to register a positive test results. Regardless of such snags, France plans to stick with the app and work to improve adoption and performance.

message_bubbles.text: **Government institute:** Ministry for Digital Affairs.
**Anonymisation method:** Centralised server assigns users a permanent ID (a pseudonym).
**Activity information:** Records of interactions between citizens logged.
**Platform:** Bluetooth data exchange via domestically developed API.
**App:** StopCovid.

**Context:** France opted to develop its own technology to underpin their contact tracing app solution, rather than using the Apple and Google-backed standard. Cédric O, France’s digital minister, claimed the app worked well from a technical standpoint, although not as well on iPhones given that Apple’s operating system prevented Bluetooth from running in the background. Sensing frustration with the app, France then called publicly for Apple and Google to weaken their privacy protections in order to integrate the Apple/Google API within its healthcare system, requesting they be “allow[ed] to develop a sovereign European health solution”. Apple and Google declined.
**Government institute:** Federal Ministry of Health, with Fraym (venture backed startup).
**Anonymisation method:** Data aggregation.
**Activity information:** Analysis of the use of open fires, inefficient fuels, rates of cigarette smoking, and age.
**Data processing:** Machine learning.

**Context:** Exposure to smoke from polluting cooking methods causes nearly 4 million premature deaths in Africa, including more than 64,600 deaths in Nigeria every year. This machine learning algorithm draws on this data , as well as age and smoking status, to understand the spatial dynamics of at-risk citizens in the area. These maps are intended to allow health officials to prepare infrastructure improvements, allocate emergency funding, and activate other Covid-19 prevention measures.
**Government institute:** Department of Health, together with Innovation and Technology Bureau.
**Identification method:** Identity information stored within smartphone app, verification of identity made when scanning QR code on wristband.
**Location information:** Sampling of the electromagnetic signals surrounding home calibrates a virtual quarantine geofence.
**Hardware:** Various formats of digital and/or printed wristbands.
**App:** StayHomeSafe.

**Context:** Hong Kong was an early-adopter of wearable ID and quarantine devices, which have been generally accepted as a sensible measure by its society. Punishments for citizens not complying with quarantine can be harsh and may lead to six months of jail time as well as fines. The punishment can also be social, as many unintended youtube stars have discovered. The sight of a wristband in public have led to videos being shared online to shame this anti-social behaviour.
**Government institute:** China National Space Administration (CNSA).
**Identification method:** Satellite geolocation integrated with ‘Skynet’; the Chinese government’s surveillance system.
**Location information:** Precise positioning of cellular devices, and coordination of surveillance system resources.
**Hardware:** 55 satellites split into 2 constellations.

**Context:** Although the BeiDou Satellite Navigation Experimental System was only completed in June 2020, it was able to provide valuable assistance in managing the viral outbreak in China. With its nationwide reach it was able to track patients at the micro scale, while analysing the pattern of the outbreak at the macro scale. Reliable data and precise mapping imagery also allowed China to precisely place thousands of new makeshift hospitals across the country. With all citizens in China’s western Xinjiang region recently ordered to install cellular trackers within their vehicles as 'a measure to combat violence and terrorism', they will now have extra protection from the virus as the constellation watches over them.
**Government institute:** National Informatics Centre (NIC).
**Identification methods:** Infected citizen's data stored centrally upon diagnosis, and published publicly.
**Location information:** Location of infected citizens revealed to others who have been in the same location (within 500m).
**Data analysis:** Combination of Bluetooth signal to measure interaction, and GPS coordinates for location.
**App:** Aarogya Setu (Bridge to health).

**Context:** This semi-mandatory app (required for all government workers) has already been downloaded more than 90 million times according to government officials. The actually number of users however is difficult to ascertain, as hackers are using additional software to duplicating their location, virtually enclosing in on semi-anonymous infected citizens to determine their exact locations.
**Government institute:** National Center for Cyber Security Technology (NCCST).
**Identification method:** All personal details and contact information stored centrally upon arrival in Taiwan, or by default as a citizen.
**Location information:** Home-quarantine enforcement through cell tower signal triangulation.
**Platform:** ‘Digital fence’ cross-department information integration.

**Context:** As citizens flew to Taiwan from China in the initial stages of the virus outbreak, there was concern from Taiwanese officials that traditional forms of quarantine would not be able to be sufficiently monitored. The solution was to create a new digital system that maximised the resources of different law, health, and communication departments. Despite unexpected police visits resulting from drained smartphone batteries, the successful containment of an epidemic by the government has score favourable public review (84 points out of 100).
**Government institute:** Regional Ministry of Health of the Balearic Islands, with University of the Balearic Islands.
**Identification information:** Proof of citizenship and health status.
**Activity intervention:** Border crossing management.
**Hardware:** Smartphone display and optical reader.
**App:** Health certification app, designed to be supported by smartphones and digital watches.

**Context:** For tourist destinations, the economic losses caused by the pandemic have been especially severe. Several technological solutions are now being proposed to get citizens back to the beach. This proposal would allow ports of entry and departure to coordinate internationally on the health status of passengers. The digital nature of this certificate would allow for the health status of citizens to be updated if they are infected during their visit.
**Government institute:** Ministry of the Interior, produced by Enova Robotics.
**Identification method:** Scanning and sending citizen's identity papers to centralised headquarters.
**Activity information:** Able to question citizens on reasons for breaking curfew, and then either sanction or persecute.
**Hardware:** Robot maneuvers on four wheels using a thermal camera and Lidar technology for navigation.
**Operating Platform:** Operated remotely by human agents, or switched to autonomous mode and operated by AI.

**Context:** In a video posted on the interior ministry’s website, the robot calls out to suspected violators of the lockdown: “What are you doing? Show me your ID. You don’t know there’s a lockdown?” It can also be heard voicing pre-recorded messages calling on citizens to “respect the law ... and stay at home to limit the spread [of the virus] and safeguard human lives”. With humans easily outpacing this slow-moving solution, it has appeared to be more effective at spreading curfew information through social media attention than on the streets.
**Government institute:** State of Qatar Ministry of Interior.
**Identification method:** Generous permissions granted to access phone data through app, including call history and photo meta-data.

**Identification and activity information:** App obtains permissions to: Location, approximate location (network-based), precise location (GPS and network-based), directly call phone numbers, read phone status and identity, photos/media/files, read the contents of user's USB storage, modify or delete the contents of user's USB storage, device ID & call information, read phone status and identity, receive data from internet, view network connections pair with Bluetooth devices, access Bluetooth settings, disable screen lock, full network access, run at startup, draw over other apps, prevent device from sleeping, among others.
**App:** Ehteraz (precaution).

**Context:** Like other governments around the world, Qatar has turned to smartphones to trace people’s movements and track who they have come into contact with, allowing officials to monitor coronavirus infections and alert people who are at risk of contagion. Qatar's app solution however grants unprecedented access to citizens’ data, with no indication of why it is needed, and how it will be used.  As a result of this app being mandatory, citizens have formed long queues to buy burner phones to protect their privacy.
**Government institute:** United Arab Emirates Ministry of the Interior, Electronic Services and Communications Department.
**Identification method:** Facial recognition.
**Activity information:** Access and monitoring of movements within public buildings.
**Software:** Transition from fingerprint scanner hardware to facial recognition cameras and software.
**Platform:** CryptoMetrics biometrics systems (Canada).

**Context:** In the run-up to the pandemic, the United Arab Emirates had already begun upgrading its surveillance network, with Dubai installing an AI powered system called “Oyoon,” or “Eyes” in Arabic. Under the umbrella of coronavirus hygiene measures, the roll-out of facial recognition technology has been extended even further, working its way into the headquarters of the police itself, where fingerprint scanners have been replaced with facial recognition cameras. The police have become part of a biometric database that controversially allows the authoritarian government the means to suppress any sign of dissent and as it tries to suppress the spread of the virus.
**Tech industry:** Mobile money service providers - Including: Airtel Money, MTN Mobile Money, Tigo Cash, Vodafone Cash.
**Identification method:** Identity information tied to digital wallet.
**Activity intervention:** Incentives for digital economic transactions.
**Platform:** Transaction data sent from dedicated SIM cards to central telecommunication servers.

**Context:** Ghana has become the fastest-growing mobile money market in Africa. But this is set to accelerate even more. With the World Health Organization flagging physical currency as a conduit for the spread of covid-19, Ghana's government has responded with incentives that aim to make mobile money companies even more attractive to users. By relaxing requirements for opening digital wallets, and lowering transaction fees, more and more transactions will become virtual. By connecting previously ‘unbanked’ users to vital resources, the mobile money industry is transforming the way users interact; reducing the need for in-person transactions, but also strengthening the government’s ability to collect much-needed revenue from its users during this time of crisis.
**Tech company:** Facebook, Inc.
**Identification method:** Monitoring and blocking user profiles.
**Activity intervention:** Restriction of spam messaging.
**Software:** Freeware, cross-platform messaging and Voice over IP (VoIP)
**App:** WhatsApp.

**Context:** In March 2020, Irish politician Taoiseach Leo Varadkar appealed to the public not to share unverified information about the coronavirus through Whatsapp. Earlier, a mass-circulated message claimed that an Irish hospital was treating young patients whose symptoms were exacerbated by taking anti-inflammatory drugs. Although hospital and medical authorities disowned this claim, some users resisted medical treatment based on this spam message. In response to this and other similar cases around the world, WhatsApp have now limited the amount of times a user can forward a message, rather than attempting to remove false information to begin with. In a statement, WhatsApp said  “We’ve seen a significant increase in the amount of forwarding, which users have told us can feel overwhelming and can contribute to the spread of misinformation. We believe it’s important to slow the spread of these messages down to keep WhatsApp a place for personal conversation.”
**Tech industry:** ETNO (Europe’s Telecommunication Network Operators), a telecommunication lobby group.
**Identity information:** Employment contracts.
**Activity intervention:** Meetings and workflow digitised to support remote working.
**Hardware:** 5G infrastructure to support a greater number of connected devices, and a greater demand for data.
**Apps:** Business communication applications.

**Context:** With a push from the telecommunication lobby group ETNO, service providers such as KPN, T-Mobile, and Orange will see their 5G ambitions fast-tracked as a means to recover from the widespread 'economic destruction' caused by the pandemic. A 750 billion euro recovery package was approved by the European Commission in June 2020 with the aim to “press fast-forward” on the EU’s digital transition.
**Tech industry:** Commercialisation of China's national surveillance system.
**Identification method:** Video surveillance, facial recognition, and GPS.
**Activity intervention:** Monitoring of curfew, vehicular restrictions, and coordination of emergency services.
**Hardware:** Network of 5,800 video surveillance cameras.
**Platform:** Integrated Security Service ECU 911.

**Context:** In 2016 Ecuador was hit by a 7.8-magnitude earthquake. China was one of the first countries to supply humanitarian aid immediately after the quake. The relationship between the two nations has been evident since, with President Xi Jinping regularly visiting the country. One such visit featured an inspection of ECU 911, a complete surveillance network purchased from the Chinese state. It was initially focused on disaster relief efforts following the earthquake, and is now being touted as a valuable weapon in the fight against covid-19.
**Tech company:** NSO Group Technologies.
**Identification method:** De-anonymisation of telecommunication data.
**Location information:** Complete cross-referenceable records of user locations.
**Software:** Codenamed ‘Fleming’ - this adaptation of the malware ‘Pegasus’ uses AI to combine identity, location, and interaction data to determine a user’s risk of infection.

**Context:** Israel-based technology firm NSO has claimed that a number of governments around the world are piloting their system, but would not reveal their identities. However, this solution may soon be launched in Israel itself, with Israel’s Defense Minister Naftali Bennett tweeting that the Israeli government is working on “world-leading” AI system that will give every citizen a grade between 1 and 10 to determine how likely they are to spread the coronavirus, and if they need to be tested.

content.title: Iran
content.status_comment: AC19 only available on third-party app stores.

message_bubbles.text: **Tech company:** Google LLC.
**Identification information:** Registration details, health status.
**Location intervention:** Use of app store for maximum reach.
**Platform:** Google Play app store.

**Context:** Iran was one of the first countries to be widely affected by Covid-19. As with many countries, it developed a contact tracing app to be distributed on the Google's ‘play’ app store. With the monopoly Google and Apple have over the distribution of apps, adhering to their terms and conditions has become a prerequisite for designing a contact tracing solution that can reach the level of adoption needed for effect. Iran fell foul of these terms and conditions, resulting in the removal of its app AC19. Without clear indications of what rules it had broken, Iran—like many nations around the world—are questioning the dominant role an international American company has in the domestic handling of a medical crisis.

content.title: Norway
content.status_comment: 15.06.2020 - App data deleted and further collection ceased.

message_bubbles.text: **Tech industry:** Telecommunication collaboration with Norwegian Institute of Public Health (NIPH).
**Identification method:** Cell-tower triangulation.
**Location information:** Records of previous and current location.
**Hardware:** Cellular network infrastructure.
**App:** Smittestopp.

**Context:** The Norwegian government was forced to discontinue the use of their COVID-19 contact tracing app after growing international criticism from the likes of Amnesty International over its invasive use of location data. Norway was one of the first European countries to deploy an app solution, but this speed meant it was released before the European Data Protection Board (of which Norway is a member) had put together guidelines, specifying that contact-tracing apps “do not require tracking the location of individual users”; and suggesting the use of “proximity data” instead.

content.title: Australia (redirected to USA)
content.status_comment: Australian parliament to review data contract

message_bubbles.text: **Tech company:** Amazon Web Services (AWS).
**Identification information:** Name, age range, mobile number, and postcode stored centrally together with decryption keys.
**Location information:** Location history obtainable with decryption.
**Hardware:** Centralised server for the storage and processing of data.
**App:** COVIDSafe.

**Context:** Members of the Australian government have raised alarms about the Federal Government’s decision to send contact tracing data offshore to US retail and technology giant Amazon. Despite assurances that user’s private information is secure, concerns have been raised about US-registered companies being accessible by US law enforcement. A sense of privacy violation has also been heightening by requests from Australian law enforcement agencies to access data for criminal cases. With falling levels of public trust in the security of a centralised data system, re-centralising data at an Australian-based server may not be enough to encourage users to continue to take part in digital contact tracing, which has so far produced no meaningful results in suppressing the spread of Covid-19.
**Tech company:** Alibaba (DAMO Academy).
**Identification information:** Health records.
**Activity information:** Rate of health decline or recovery.
**Software:** AI analysis of computed tomography (CT) images of patients’ lungs, stored and distributed on cloud server.
**Platform:** Alibaba Cloud.

**Context:** The system was trained on images and data from 5,000 confirmed coronavirus cases, and has already been tested in hospitals throughout China. With this technology now being offered to other countries around the world, it can be considered a diplomatic overture. It is however underscored with economic ambitions. By expanding into Japan through using a “no charge” strategy for accessing this technology, as well as allowing suppliers to set up booths on the Alibaba shopping site free of charge, it is set to see an substantial increase in its market share of online retail, its main line of business.
**Tech company:** Apple and Google collaboration.
**Anonymisation method:** Anonymous key exchange, data stored locally on user’s device.
**Activity information:** Records of close and prolonged proximity with other users.
**Software:** Integrated within smartphone operating system.
**Platform:** Exposure Notification API for iOS and Android.

**Context:** Despite this API being designed by two American companies, only one state, Virginia, has used this technique within a contact tracing app, while 20 others ‘explore’ the possibility. Its popularity is international however, with many countries retiring efforts do develop their own app from the ground up, to instead build upon Apple and Google's platform. Not only does it offer the most advanced privacy protection standard of any contact tracing app, it also allows contact tracing apps to run bluetooth proximity identifier software in the background; a major stumbling block for other Bluetooth systems which must remain 'always open' - badly affecting battery life. The monopoly that these two companies have over the operating system of 99.9% of smartphones worldwide forces governments to be dictated by the privacy standards they define.
**Tech companies:** Fitbit, Apple, Samsung, Garmin, among others.
**Anonymisation method:** Pseudonym assigned to each user.
**Activity information:** Body activity, with key measurement of resting heart rate.
**Hardware:** Accelerometers, temperature, and optical sensors.
**App:** Corona-Datenspende (Corona Data Donation app)

**Context:** This app uses algorithms to identify various trends in a user's bodily data, that when analysed together with confirmed covid-19 cases, seeks to provide a warning system for possible infection. With more than 50,000 users having downloaded this app so far, their enthusiasm for quantifying workouts seems to effectively translate to monitoring the virus through participating in this data-sharing exercise.
**Tech industry:** Smartphone chip manufacturers.
**Anonymisation method:** Anonymous Bluetooth key exchange.
**Activity information:** Records of interactions between users logged.
**Hardware:** Bluetooth transmitter and receiver.
**Platform:** Short-link radio wave standard.

**Context:** Denmark’s initial contact tracing app, ‘SmitteStop’, was withdrawn from use due to privacy concerns involving invasive location data methods. It was later relaunched using Bluetooth sensing and Apple/Google’s privacy preserving API. In the neighbouring country of Sweden however, the two inventors of Bluetooth technology have cast doubt over the utility of this technology in the pandemic context. Originally designed to send audio data to headsets, this technology has now been tasked to keep us safe; something the inventors say is impossibly inaccurate, claiming that interference of something as innocuous as bush can result in a person who standing 1m away, appear as if they’re 10m away to a Bluetooth sensor. The name of “Bluetooth” Gormsson—the 10th-century Scandinavian king who united various tribes in what is now Denmark and Sweden—will still be used today to describe the connection between devices, but it is perhaps ironic that the use of this technology is now dividing these two nations.
**Tech companies:** High Performance Computing (HPC) Consortium, consisting of IBM, Amazon Web Services, AMD, Dell Technologies, Google Cloud, Microsoft, Intel, among others.
**Anonymisation method:** Data aggregation.
**Location information:** Population density in relation to location of treatment facilities.
**Hardware:** $200 million (USD) supercomputer - IBM AC922 system utilizing 4,608 computer servers.
**Platform:** Microsoft AI for Health.

**Context:** The Consortium is supporting the Nepal Applied Mathematics and Informatics Institute for Research (NAAMII) to run an assemblage of simulations, each corresponding to a different disease outbreak scenario. The results provide a strategy for optimal intervention to halt the progression of the disease, becoming a resource for policy makers in Nepal and around the world to make informed decisions to fight the Covid-19 crisis.
**Tech company:** Alphabet Inc.
**Anonymisation method:** Data aggregation.
**Location information:** GPS location of users relative to public transport routes.
**App:** Google Maps.

**Context:** Google Maps users are now being warned of crowded public transport routes and stations - anticipating the risk of contagion. In international tourist destinations, such as Amsterdam, this initiative has been welcomed as a means of communicating vital health information widely, through different languages. As the rules around the wearing of face masks in public spaces are being imposed and lifted in dynamic response to infection rates, Google Maps is also keeping users up to date by informing users if they should be wearing a mask in their current location.
**Tech company:** Alphabet Inc.
**Anonymisation and Identification:** As an extension of internet infrastructure, anonymity depends on a user’s engagement with it.
**Location intervention:** Removal of internet white spots.
**Hardware:** 35 “floating cell towers” constructed from tennis-court-sized sheets of polyethylene. Powered by solar panels.
**Platform:** 4G coverage - 18.9Mbps download speed, 4.7Mbps upload speed.

**Context:** This long-term project has now being fast-tracked to help improve communications during the coronavirus pandemic, aiding government efforts to “address and manage the spread” of Covid-19, with access to emergency services a priority, alongside connecting people. The data protections that have been implemented in Western nations alongside the rise of the companies like google, do not exist uniformly in the resource-rich, infrastructure-poor African countries, where Western tech is using the pandemic to further establish its presence. As the Loon balloon floats autonomously overhead, this solution also challenges the autonomy of African nations to set their own data protection standards.
**Tech company:** Facebook, Inc.
**Anonymisation method:** Data aggregation.
**Location information:** Location of smartphone while charging.
**Hardware:** Smartphone in combination with electricity infrastructure.
**Apps:** Facebook, Messenger, WhatsApp, Instagram.

**Context:** Through collecting granular information about the status of a user’s smartphone, such as battery, storage, and signal, Facebook is able to ascertain a complex view of user mobility during the pandemic. The habits of users associated to this information enables Facebook to gain deeper insights into user's response to ‘stay at home’ restrictions. This data is then made public through Facebook's ‘Data for Good’ program, giving governments and research institutes ‘real’ data on user’s movements. This was especially crucial in Italy, where a so-called “exodus” of people from North to South was emphasised by the media, which, as Facebook data shows, did not actually happen.

content.view_deployment_button: View solution in use around the world

question.message: Browse the globe to find new and amazing solutions, or click the button below for more guidance.
